Introduction

Mastitis, a common condition, causes pain and inflammation of the breast and is rarely complicated by the formation of a breast abscess.  This condition most commonly occurs in lactating women (ie, lactational mastitis).  Nonlactational mastitis is less common and includes idiopathic granulomatous mastitis and periductal mastitis.  This article focuses on lactational mastitis and breast abscess.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Lactational mastitis is common in breastfeeding women due to inadequate milk duct drainage.  Women are at greatest risk for mastitis during the first 3 months postpartum, when breastfeeding is still becoming established.  Difficulties with breastfeeding (eg, poor latching) can lead to prolonged engorgement, inadequate milk drainage, and clogged milk ducts.  Bacteria from the infant's nasopharynx or the maternal skin, such as Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus species, are then transmitted through the nipple and multiply in stagnant milk, resulting in infection.  If untreated, the infection can progress, forming a localized collection of pus known as a breast abscess.



Risk factors are based mostly on breast engorgement and inadequate milk drainage and include:



  • Poor breastfeeding technique (ie, poor latch):  ineffective emptying of the breast that can lead to milk stasis or skin trauma
  • Nipple trauma:  cracked or excoriated nipples, which can allow bacteria to enter
  • Replacing nursing with formula or pumped breast milk
  • Sudden increase in sleep duration, weaning, or wearing of tight clothing


Additional risk factors include a history of mastitis and immunosuppression (eg, diabetes mellitus, chronic steroid use).

Clinical presentation



Patients with lactational mastitis (

figure 1
) typically have:



  • Unilateral breast pain and erythema, which may initially be localized but can spread to encompass the entire breast
  • Flu-like symptoms (eg, fever, malaise, myalgia)
  • Symptoms that are often preceded by reduced milk secretion from the affected breast, prolonged times between feedings, or localized skin trauma to the nipple


Patients with a breast abscess (

figure 2
) typically have symptoms of lactational mastitis and a palpable, fluctuant mass.  These findings may present with mastitis or develop days to weeks later.



Mastitis and breast abscess can rarely cause severe illness, particularly when they are not diagnosed and treated early.  These patients can develop sepsis and may have symptoms of lactational mastitis and/or breast abscess, as well as altered mental status and hemodynamic instability (eg, hypotension, tachycardia).

Differential diagnosis



  • Engorgement:  Physiologic interstitial edema of breast tissue typically occurs within a week of delivery, causing bilateral generalized breast pain that may be accompanied by a low-grade fever.
  • Plugged duct:  Focal edema causes narrowing of milk ducts, resulting in localized tenderness and, often, a small palpable lump that typically resolves within 48 hours with continued breastfeeding.  Systemic symptoms (eg, fever) are absent.
  • Galactocele (
    figure 3
    ):  A cyst of retained milk can present during pregnancy or the postpartum period with a palpable mass.  Unlike breast abscesses, galactoceles are not painful and are not accompanied by systemic symptoms.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer (
    figure 4
    ):  Rapid onset of localized breast erythema and edema occurs, often without fever or significant pain.  Unlike mastitis, inflammatory breast cancer often causes nipple retraction and thickened skin with a peau d'orange appearance.

Diagnosis



Mastitis is diagnosed clinically when a lactating patient with breast pain is found to have the characteristic physical examination findings of mastitis (eg, localized breast edema, tenderness, erythema).  Imaging and laboratory evaluation are unnecessary for the diagnosis but may be helpful in patients with severe illness or those whose mastitis does not respond to initial treatment.



A breast abscess should be suspected in patients with symptoms of mastitis who have a tender fluctuant mass palpable on breast examination or patients whose condition does not respond to antibiotic treatment.  Ultrasonography typically reveals loculated fluid.

Management



All patients should receive supportive care to relieve pain, ductal obstruction, and inflammation.  Such care includes the application of cool compresses, continued breastfeeding or expression of milk every 2-3 hours (to relieve milk stasis), and analgesics (eg, acetaminophen, ibuprofen).



Empiric treatment of lactational mastitis is with antibiotics effective against methicillin-sensitive S aureus (eg, dicloxacillin, cephalexin).  Women with risk factors for methicillin-resistant S aureus (eg, recent antibiotic therapy) are treated with clindamycin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, or vancomycin.



Most cases of mastitis respond to antibiotics within 1-2 days; however, some patients can retain infected, stagnant milk that can lead to breast abscess formation (which is less susceptible to antibiotic penetration due to its walled-off cavity).  When patients have fluctuant breast masses and/or when their condition does not respond to antibiotics, breast ultrasonography is required to evaluate for an abscess.



If an abscess is identified, management is with incision and drainage (through either ultrasonography-guided needle aspiration or surgical incision and drainage) and continued antibiotics.

Prognosis



Mastitis generally responds to appropriate antibiotic therapy and supportive measures.  Early intervention minimizes complications such as breast abscess and sepsis.  The prognosis for breast abscess is good with proper drainage and antibiotic therapy.  However, recurrence is possible, necessitating attention to modifiable risk factors (eg, breastfeeding technique, tobacco cessation).



Most patients with mastitis or breast abscess can continue breastfeeding.  Any suspected breast infection that does not resolve with appropriate treatment should raise concern for inflammatory breast cancer, even in lactating women.

Summary
